In the meantime, I got a call back from my contact at Abdullah. He told me the money had been transferred to O’Hennessy Capital Management, located in the Isle of Man. Isle of Man is a tiny island located between Great Britain and Ireland. It’s a well-known tax and gambling haven, playing host to dozens of poker websites. The account rep was also able to give me one small but crucial piece of information. Through his contacts on the Isle of Man, the rep obtained the name of the account holder: Kensington R. Danforth. I chuckled out loud upon hearing the name. It was a classic Mordecai alias.


Three hours later, I had assembled the cell cloning rig. At least according to some Serbian hacker.

I flipped the switch and said a little prayer. There was a short, sending sparks into the air. Fuck.

Examining the gear revealed a blown transistor. Turns out I’d soldered the wrong wire. The circuit board was still intact, though. I double-checked the instructions and found the error. After soldering a few more wires together, I crossed my fingers and flipped the switch. The modulator hummed to life.

I had a dog, and bing-go was his name-o.

A quick GMail search revealed Mordecai’s college cell number. The setup used a USB chip, which allowed configuration via linux.

After opening a bash shell, I typed in the commands:

> mount /dev/sdb /ownleroy/cell

> ./klone /ownleroy/cell 617-239-[redacted]

> ./klone-activate /ownleroy/cell

The phone rebooted before taking the new settings. The signal strength was low, so I moved the antennae and booster around the room before finding the sweet spot.

Another reboot. Signal strength: four bars. Not bad. Using the cloned phone, I sent my burner a text message: “hello, world.”

Sure enough, chirp chirp. My burner lit up. Sure enough, the sender’s phone number was 617-239-[redacted].

I opened a fresh Chrome instance and went through the process of resetting Leroy’s GMail password. After hitting the “Send Recovery Text to Your Phone” option, the clone chirped to life.

Mr. Leroy Brown–you just got 0wned.


Mordecai was still emailing some chicks he’d met at Harvard. Women had always been his achilles, apparently.

After a few clicks, it became evident that Leroy’s GMail archive would do little for me. His last sent message was over a week old. But Leroy’s not the most tech-savvy con in the world. Google has a little-known feature called “Enable Search History.” Sounds harmless enough. But it means Google (and anyone logged into your Google account) has access to your entire search history.

Turns out, Mordecai had failed to disable this feature. After a few clicks, Leroy’s helpful Big Brother–I mean Google–was listing every search term he’d ever entered.

The moneyshot was just a few inches down on the list:

arkansas national bank little rock

entry.title: Chapter 17
entry.content:
Cray Wench and his federal boys were cold on the trail of one Mr. Leroy Brown. I was sure they knew about me, as in, someone like me, but they did not yet have my real name. Not yet. I bounced my trading sessions through so many web proxies and SSH tunnels, it would take months to get warrants from all of the providers. Let alone the obstacle of international service providers. Why should a hosting company in Sweden comply with the request of an American court? Or, think of it this way: should Exxon Mobil just hand over its server logs if it were demanded by an Iranian court of law? Of course not.

Three different companies had passed along our keysniffers to the FBI’s Cybercrimes division. These companies, at the request of the FBI, also forwarded all employee, visitor and contractor logs. But Wench was stuck; none of the names yielded any clues.

He had a hunch, though. After making a few calls, Cray Wench discovered that all three NYC-based companies used the same janitorial services contractor. Wench made some calls and learned that at one point, one Mr. Franz Abignail had been the cleaning crew manager on duty at all three locations. As it turned out, Abignail was one very poorly chosen alias by Mordecai. He happened to work these jobs, as I was busy managing the growth of our technical infrastructure. He must’ve gotten sloppy, planting the sniffers on low-value, high-risk targets.

The cleaning firm sent over a copy of Abignail’s fake ID, giving Wench another vital piece of the ever-growing puzzle.


Mordecai’s headshot made the rounds across every FBI office in the nation. An APB of sorts. At the Boston FBI office, one enterprising young agent thought the elaborate insider trading scam sounded familiar. The work of a real long con. One with brains to boot. Among Boston agents, there was lore of a suspected Harvard infiltrator, but because the University refused to press charges, the Feds never got involved. The enterprising agent took Abignail’s headshot down to Harvard. The Administration still refused to acknowledge the existence of Mordecai.

After several meetings, the agency came away empty-handed. The next day, however, the young agent received a mysterious, FedEx package. It was the complete Harvard file on Mordecai. His freshman-year photo indicated that Franz Abignail was in fact the same individual who had cheated his way into Harvard. As part of the agreement, Mordecai gave up his real identity to the Harvard administration: Lawrence Brown.

The federalies’ investigation now had legs. Wench went public the next morning; Leroy’s mug was splashed across every major paper in the nation. Down at my local Starbucks the next morning, I froze in horror as Leroy’s visage stared back at me. “Ex-Harvard Con Turned Insider Trading Millionaire” read the headline. I hustled home to check Google News.

“Former Harvard Student Caught in Elaborate Con” read the headline in USA Today. The Wall Street Journal ran with: “From Harvard to Janitor, to Insider Trading Tycoon.”


I had to get down to Little Rock. Somehow. In the previous six months, I’d obtained three valid driver’s licenses. New York, New Jersey and California. It was me in the picture, but the identities belonged to someone else. A real person who had the same height/build/etc. Also–one valid US passport, created in similar fashion; another from New Zealand.

It was time to hit the road. I packed my best three laptops, some externals and my surveillance gear. Oh, and $150k in cash that I’d set aside for this kind of occasion (a rainy day kind of fund).

In an ideal world, I’d have time to run Boot & Nuke on all of my hard disks before taking off. Most people think you can just reformat a hard drive and the data is gone. But if you’ve ever seen CSI, you know that the latent data is still there, lurking. Millions of incriminating 1s and 0s.

I ejected all of my drives and collected the remaining USB jump sticks. Wrapped in several garbage bags, duct-taped to a brick, the Wallabout Bay would have to be the final resting place of my beloved terabytes. I made about seventeen turns along the way. I donned a Yankees cap, parked the car and walked out on the bridge. I could barely hear the plop as the bag descended to the bottom of the Bay.


Dark sunglasses and a Yankees cap were the best I could do for a disguise. A quick trip to Avis and I was on the road, headed south in a mid-sized sedan. Traveling by air would be too risky. The drive to Little Rock took a full two days, as speeding was not a luxury I could afford.

In Little Rock, I settled into a cheap motel. Hopped on their shitty Wifi and found a local PI by the name of Jimmy Radcliffe. He was your tried and true dick. Wore a shabby brown sports coat with patches on the elbows. Said he mostly handled divorce cases. Dick and Janes who thought their significant other was porking the office hottie. We chatted for a few, then he said, “Yeah, most private investigators are ex-law enforcement. Fuckin’ pigs. I come from … let’s just say, not that line of work.” I’d found my man.

“Jimmy, I’m looking for an investigator with a certain … eye for discretion. In exchange, I’m willing to pay. And pay well.”

Jimmy uncrossed his fingers, leaned over and picked up a cigar. The thing was massive (think Bob Marley). He said, “I … believe that can be arranged.”

I took out ten g’s and laid it on him. He flipped through the bills.

“Yeah, this’ll work,” he said.

“Just a retainer,” I said. “You never told me your rate.”

“Sixty dollars per hour.”

“I’ll triple that. But the remaining two thirds will be held in escrow until six months after our business completes.”

He mulled over my proposal, bellowing huge rings of smoke into the air.

“Cash?” he asked.

“Of course,” I said. “The remaining two thirds will be delivered to you via FedEx, assuming the confidentiality of our arrangement remains intact.”

A smile crept across his mustached face. “Deal,” he said.

entry.title: Chapter 18
entry.content:
Armed with Mordecai’s list of aliases, Jimmy went to work on locating our man. The third hotel he tried was the downtown Hyatt Regency.

“Hello,” said Jimmy, “can you patch me through to Kensington Danforth? It’s urgent. He’s staying in room 712.”

“Sure, just a second.” A beat. “Sir, our records indicate he’s staying in room 420. Perhaps he’s changed rooms since you’ve last spoken with him. Here, I’ll patch you through.”

Got him.

Jimmy setup a surveillance operation at the Hyatt; meanwhile I posted up outside Arkansas National Bank.

After a day of that, I grew restless. After a trip to the local spy shop, I was in business. Posing as an electrician, I installed two spy cams across the street from the bank. One above a coffee shop, the other beneath a neon “Diner” sign. With a lens the size of a button, the cameras were nearly invisible to the naked eye. They beamed a live feed to a nearby 3G modem. From there the data was sent directly to my server farm in Amsterdam.

I sat back, turned on HBO (quite a perk for the cheap motel), watched, and waited.


That night, Leroy showed up at the hotel, wasted. “Yeah, he’s with some broad,” said Jimmy. “Quite the looker. She’s got those uh … I mean no disrespect, but whaddya call those–hooker boots? The black leather thigh-highs.”

“Yeah, that sounds like Leroy alright. There’s one thing you should know,” I said to Jimmy, “Leroy’s quite the fan of the ladies, and he doesn’t seem to mind paying for it, if ya know what I mean.”

“Loud and clear.”

The next day, I get a text from Jimmy: “Bishop has left the palace.”

A few hours later I’m watching the live feed when Jimmy pulls up in a Lincoln Town Car. He’s dressed to the nines in a pinstripe suit. Two women get out of the car with him. “Bishop is in the pocket,” I text Jimmy.

He’d lost the tail at the airport parking lot, so it was a good thing we had the live feed.

From what emerged of the case later, we know that Leroy had opened the bank account under the name “ATM Distributors Global, Inc.” There was a major ATM distributor by the same name, only, without the Global. These are the people who made a fortune by stocking every mini-part, strip joint and fast-food shop with an ATM.

Leroy’s “assistants” turned out to be high-end escorts. Some $1000 dollar an hour agency that flies in girls from London, Tokyo and Paris. Apparently, the branch manager wanted to meet the man behind such a large cash infusion.

“Our business is very cash-intensive, as you can imagine,” Leroy told the manager. “We’ve blanketed the Northeast with our machines, but see a huge opportunity for us to expand in the South. Please, don’t mention this to the press, but we are about to acquire one of our major competitors in the Southeast. Hence the infusion of capital in this market.”

“Of course, Mr. Danforth. And we are glad to have your business. Thank you for meeting me in person. Is there anything else we can help you with today?”

Mordecai looked to his assistants. “The withdrawals,” one said.

“Ah yes,” said Mordecai, “we will begin making withdrawals next week. Does Tuesday work for you?”

“Of course. How much are we talking about?”

“Twenty-five million.”

The branch manager suddenly found it difficult to swallow. But he did so anyway.

“That’s quite the sum.”

“Our southern operations are doing quite well of late. An ever-increasing number of small businesses are opting to accept cash only. Our machines go in the corner. Customers get their cash. Everyone is happy, just about.”

“I see.” It seemed to make sense to the manager. And how could he explain turning down hundreds of millions in business to his boss?

“We’ll need an armored car to transport the funds to our secure holding facility. Will there be a charge for that?”

“No, Mr. Danforth. Let me check with my boss, but I believe we’d be happy to provide that service to a client such as yourself.”

“Great. I believe that’s all.” Leroy turned to his assistants. “Shall we?”

“It’s a pleasure doing business with you,” said the branch manager.

“And you, too.”


While Mordecai was doing business at the bank, I broke into his hotel room. It was simple, really. Using a magnetic card writer and cracked database of common key formats, I cloned Mordecai’s room key.

The lamp fixture provided some camouflage for a hidden mic. Off in the corner of the room, I installed a spy cam. By the time I ducked out to my rental car, the feed was live.


The next morning, after a night of carnal activities with his “assistants,” Mordecai made a call. The mic audio was kind of fuzzy. All I heard was: “Yeah, this is Kensington … ATM Distributors … I’ll be … an hour … 5150 Oa… I’ll see you there.”

Jimmy lost the tale on Mordecai’s red Corvette convertible. Mordecai had this habit of driving out to the airport and swapping cars, before engaging in illicit activities. Personally, I think he got the idea from that scene in Goodfellas. The one where Ray Liotta’s character is driving around town everywhere while trying to make meatballs. He thinks he’s just paranoid, but it turns out he really is being followed by helicopters.

All I had to go on was “5150 Oa”–not much, really. Google Maps to the rescue. The auto-complete feature narrowed down the address to one of two options: Oak Avenue and Oak Dale Drive. Jimmy took the Avenue while I scoped out the Drive.

Thirty minutes later I got a text from Jimmy. “It’s 5150 Oak Avenue. 100%.” I made my way over.

Mordecai had really outdone himself this time. It was a large warehouse in an industrial district. “ATM Distributors Global, Inc.” read the freshly-painted sign.

I had a sinking feeling in my stomach. Leroy had really stepped up his game. For a moment, I considered turning states evidence and narcing out Mordecai. Or phoning in an anonymous tip to the Feds.

Just then though, three large trucks pulled up to the address. Jimmy and I watched from down the black. Mordecai directed traffic as the construction workers carried large steel sheets into the building.

The fucker. He was construction a vault.

entry.title: Chapter 19
entry.content:
Tuesday morning, Mordecai’s Lincoln pulled up to the bank. A senior bank VP had come out to supervise the operation. He shook Leroy’s hand and escorted him into the bank. There they signed some legal documents making the transfer official. Leroy and his female entourage got back in the Lincoln. They followed the armored car, a few lengths behind.

Over the course of a week, Mordecai had transformed his warehouse into a veritable fortress, replete with rent-a-cops. The armored car pulled up around back. The guards unloaded three pallets worth of cash. Twenties and tens, mostly.

Then we waited. Every rent-a-cop we’d spotted had left the building by five p.m., but Leroy didn’t leave the entire night. I pictured him in there, like Scrooge McDuck, swan-diving into massive piles of cash.

Jimmy kept a vigil while I headed back to the motel. We’d have to work in shifts to monitor Leroy and the cash, 24/7.


But the cash never moved. And neither did Mordecai. Every night, around ten, he’d get Chinese food delivered. But that’s all I ever saw of him.

Sure, I knew … on some level, I could go in there, guns blazing, and take the $25 million. There was always the digital approach. But I didn’t have access to Leroy’s laptop or banking codes. So e-theft was out.

If I robbed Leroy and grabbed the $25 million, what would happen to the rest? That’s what held me back the most. I could tie up Mordecai and leave him for the Feds, but then he’d turn states evidence against me. I could leave and grant Mordecai his freedom, but then he’d just walk away with $275 million. Half of which was mine. Well, technically, it belonged to hundreds of thousands of different investors, each of whom lost a few pennies to a few dollars, but still. It was now mine.

So we waited.


Over the following two weeks, three more shipments of cash arrived, bringing the total to $100 million.

Early Friday morning, we were greeted with a surprise. Through all of our surveillance and monitoring, somehow we missed it. An even-larger armored truck pulled up to the back of Leroy’s little warehouse turned bank vault. The side of the truck read “Rothstein Precious Metals.” The cargo was sealed in black tarps. The guards unloaded crate after crate of whatever it was Mordecai had purchased.

I decided it was time to make a move. That night I’d go in for the dough. A real smash and grab job, if that’s what it took. Jimmy supplied me with a glock, but I didn’t bother loading it. I’d rather go to prison, or end up dead, than actually have to shoot someone.


Sometime after ten, Mordecai finally left the warehouse. At last: a golden opportunity. I picked the lock and entered the back entrance.

It looked official alright. But a little poking around revealed the entire vault to be a sham. I went around to the side of the building, where for the first time I noticed a side door. It was a gaping hole in our surveillance. One could easily cut through the buildings next door, down a small path, and out to the street.

I went back inside and noticed an area near the ceiling–about four inches–where the vault did not extend. I came back with a ladder. My hands were shaking as I made my way to the top.

I poked my head over the steel divider and peered down.

Fuck fuck fuck fuck fuck motherfucker cocksucker motherfucker. It was gone. All of it. The precious metals (whatever it was), the cash–all of it. I got the hell outta there and called Jimmy.

“Do you have him?” I demanded.

“No, I’m just waiting at the hotel.”

“Call me as soon as you see him. I’m going back to the motel and seeing if the GPS trackers I ordered have come in. From now on, we need eyes and ears on target, twenty-four seven.”

“Got it, boss. Oh and, I know it’s a bad time … but about my payment?”

“I’ll bring thirty g’s cash to the hotel. Will that be enough for now?”

“Sure thing, boss.”

entry.title: Chapter 20
entry.content:
At the airport parking lot, I managed to track down Mordecai’s Lincoln Town Car, and his SUV. I installed a GPS tracker in each.

When Mordecai showed up at the hotel, Jimmy planted one on his Corvette.

I watched on the feed as Mordecai freshened up and put on his Sunday best. It was five a.m.–what the fuck was he up to?

“Jimmy, I’ll take it from here,” I said as Leroy pulled out of the parking lot and headed toward the freeway. Our little game of cat and mouse was nearing its climax. I didn’t want Jimmy around, getting any bright ideas.

I gave Mordecai a few miles berth as he headed east on I-40. The GPS indicated that he’d stopped, a few miles outside Fayetteville.


It was a long country road. Two blocks away, I could see Mordecai’s red corvette in the driveway. An older lady stepped out onto the porch as he was leaving. She gave him a hug; an affectionate kiss on the cheek.

Mordecai pulled out and headed down the street. A few blocks over he turned up a long dirt road. I had to keep my distance, but I watched as he drove to the end of the road and pulled up next to a large wooden shed. He unlocked the shed and stepped inside. Just checking on your stash, my boy? What, you gonna spend the night here, too?

Apparently, no. I kept driving on the main road, but I could see the corvette, and the shed. My GPS indicated that he’d taken off, and was headed back toward the freeway. I circled the car around to get a better look at the shed.

The contents were secured with a large metal padlock. I wanted to take the money and run, but there was just one problem: I was driving a mid-sized Toyota Corolla. Not the most efficient hauler.

I rushed over to UHaul, then the hardware store. I couldn’t help but haul ass down the freeway, back to the shed. A few smashes with the sledgehammer and the lock hinges were obliterated. I swung open the doors to reveal …
